{{Infobox album | Name = Watchmen: Music from the Motion Picture | Type = soundtrack | Artist = Various Artists | Cover = Cover watchmen soundtrack.jpg | Released = {{start date|2009|03|03}} | Recorded = | Genre = [[Soundtrack]] | Length = 51:13 | Label = [[Reprise Records|Reprise]] | Producers = [[Lawrence Gordon]], [[Lloyd Levin]], [[Diarmuid Quinn]], [[Xavier Ramos]], [[Deborah Snyder]], [[Zack Snyder]], [[Tom Whalley]] | Last album = | This album = | Next album = | Misc = }} {{Album ratings |rev1 = [[Allmusic]] |rev1score = {{Rating|3.5|5}}[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1479524|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic review] |rev2 = ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' |rev2score = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?SID=10186|work=Empire|author=Graydon, Danny|accessdate=February 8, 2010|title=Review of Watchmen: Music from the Motion Picture}} }} '''''Watchmen: Music from the Motion Picture''''' is the film [[soundtrack]] album for the 2009 film ''[[Watchmen (film)|Watchmen]]''. The soundtrack features three songs written by Bob Dylan: "[[Desolation Row]]", "[[The Times They Are a-Changin' (song)|The Times They Are a-Changin']]", and "[[All Along The Watchtower]]". The film uses some of the songs mentioned in the comic, including "The Times They Are a-Changin'", [[Jimi Hendrix]]'s cover of "All Along the Watchtower"; [[Simon and Garfunkel]]'s "[[The Sounds of Silence]]"; [[Nena]]'s "[[99 Luftballons]]"; a [[muzak]] version of [[Tears For Fears]]' "[[Everybody Wants to Rule the World]]"; and [[Nat King Cole]]'s "[[Unforgettable (song)|Unforgettable]]".{{cite news|author=Larry Carroll|title=Snyder Reveals Hendrix, Dylan, Other Tracks in âWatchmen,â No Smashing Pumpkins|work=[[MTV]] Splash Page|date=2008-07-23|url=http://splashpage.mtv.com/2008/07/23/snyder-reveals-hendrix-dylan-other-tracks-in-watchmen-no-smashing-pumpkins/|accessdate=2008-07-23}} Many of the period songs were up-mixed to 5.1 surround for the film using the [[Penteo]] process.{{cite web|title=Penteo process|url=http://www.penteosurround.com|publisher=PenteoSurround.com|accessdate=2009-02-12}} Bates said the challenge was composing music that would transition effectively into these famous songs.{{cite news|author=Spencer D.|title=Watchmen Composer Sounds Off|work=[[IGN]]|date=2009-02-06|url=http://uk.music.ign.com/articles/952/952338p1.html|accessdate=2009-02-08}} Snyder and Bates received Dylan's permission to use the [[stem (music)|stems]] from "The Times They Are a-Changin'" so the three-minute song could play over the six minute opening.{{cite news|url=http://www.mania.com/watches-watchmen_article_113476.html|title=He Watches the Watchmen|author=Rob Vaux|work=Mania|date=2009-03-06|accessdate=2009-03-07}} The story of how Dr. Manhattan came to be is accompanied by a montage of the pieces "Prophecies" and "Pruit Igoe" by [[Philip Glass]], originally composed for the 1983 cult film ''[[Koyaanisqatsi]]'' . Nite Owl II and Silk Spectre II's sex scene aboard the Owl Ship is set to the tune of [[Leonard Cohen]]'s "[[Hallelujah (Leonard Cohen song)|Hallelujah]]". Originally Zack Snyder used a recording of the song by [[Allison Crowe]] for the scene, but decided Crowe's version was "too romantic" and "too sexy" for a scene that is intended to come across as ironic and "ridiculous". Snyder ended up placing the original Cohen studio recording in this scene.{{cite web|url=http://www.craveonline.com/articles/filmtv/04653139/2/zack_snyder_talks_watchmen.html|title=Crave Online: Zack This line is also quoted at the end of the chapter. The music video for My Chemical Romance's version was directed by [[Zack Snyder]] (who also directed the ''Watchmen'' film and, as a result, features similar effects to that of the film). It features the band playing in an old-school punk arena. After the show becomes sold out and dozens of fans can't get in, a riot ensues as the band plays on. Eventually the police arrive but are too powerless to stop the rioting both inside the show and out. Eventually a SWAT team arrives, arrests the band, and disperses the rioters. During MCR's parts in the video multiple ''Watchmen'' imagery (such as [[Rorschach (comics)|Rorschach]]'s mask and [[Characters of Watchmen#Comedian|The Comedian]]'s smiley face button) are seen. My Chemical Romance's [[Gerard Way]] has stated in interviews that he is a long time fan of the ''Watchmen'' graphic novel. ''Watchmen'' comic book merchandise can be seen in his home on the DVD ''[[Life on the Murder Scene]]''. The song was also the last to feature former drummer Bob Bryar, who left the band a little over a year after the song was released and in the early stages of recording their fourth album ''[[Danger Days: The True Lives of the Fabulous Killjoys]]''. ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !align="left"|Chart (2009) !align="left"|Peak
